crate_groups.name: Common
crate_groups.description: Very commonly used crates that everyone should know about

crates.name: rand
crates.notes: De facto standard random number generation library split out from the standard library

crates.name: time
crates.notes: The original datetime crate which was split out of std pre-rust-1.0. Preferrable if covers your needs, but it's quite limited in what it provides.

crates.name: chrono
crates.notes: The most comphrehensive and full-featured datetime library, but more complex because of it.

crates.name: serde
crates.notes: De facto standard serialization library. Use in conjunction with sub-crates like serde_json for the specific format that you are using.

crates.name: regex
crates.notes: De facto standard regex library. Very fast, but does not support fancier features such as backtracking.

crates.name: fancy_regex
crates.notes: Use if need features such as backtracking which regex doesn't support

crates.name: uuid
crates.notes: Implements generating and parsing UUIDs and a number of utility functions

crates.name: tempfile
crates.notes: Supports both temporary files and temporary directories

crates.name: flate2
crates.notes: Uses a pure-Rust implementation by default. Use feature flags to opt in to system zlib.

crates.name: indexmap
crates.notes: A HashMap that seperately keeps track of insertion order and allows you to efficiently iterate over its elements in that order

crates.name: arrayvec
crates.notes: Arrays that are ONLY stack-allocated with fixed capacity

crates.name: smallvec
crates.notes: Arrays that are stack-allocated with fallback to the heap if the fixed stack capacity is exceeded

crates.name: tinyvec
crates.notes: Stack allocated arrays in 100% safe Rust code but requires items to implement the Default trait.

crates.name: reqwest
crates.notes: Full-fat HTTP client. Can be used in both synchronous and asynchronous code. Requires tokio runtime.

crates.name: ureq
crates.notes: Minimal synchronous HTTP client focussed on simplicity and minimising dependencies.

subgroups.name: Error Handling
subgroups.description: Crates for more easily handling errors

crates.name: anyhow
crates.notes: Provides a boxed error type that can hold any error, and helpers for generating an application-level stack trace.

crates.name: thiserror
crates.notes: Helps with generating boilerplate for enum-style error types.

subgroups.name: Logging
subgroups.description: Crates for logging. Note that in general you will need a seperate crate for actually printing/storing the logs

crates.name: tracing
crates.notes: Tracing is now the go-to crate for logging.

crates.name: log
crates.notes: An older and simpler crate if your needs are simple and you are not using any async code.

crates.name: tracing
crates.notes: Tracing is now the go-to crate for logging.

crates.name: slog
crates.notes: Structured logging

subgroups.name: Language Extensions
subgroups.description: General purpose utility crates that extend language and/or stdlib functionality.

crates.name: once_cell
crates.notes: Newer crate with more ergonomic API. On track to be incorporated into the standard library. Should be preferred for all new projects.

crates.name: lazy_static
crates.notes: Older crate. API is less convenient, but crate is stable and maintained.

crates.name: itertools
crates.notes: A bunch of useful methods on iterators that aren't in the stdlib

crates.name: num
crates.notes: Traits like Number, Add, etc that allow you write functions that are generic over the specific numeric type

crates.name: byteorder
crates.notes: Utility functions to convert between different endianness or read/write data with a specific endianness

crates.name: bitflags
crates.notes: Strongly typed bitflag types

subgroups.name: System
subgroups.description: For low-level interaction with the underling platform / operating system

crates.name: memmap2
crates.notes: The older memmap crate is unmaintained.

crates.name: libc
crates.notes: Bindings for directly calling libc functions.

crates.name: windows
crates.notes: The official Microsoft-provided crate for interacting with windows APIs

crates.name: winapi
crates.notes: Older binding to the windows APIs. Unofficial, but more complete than windows-rs

crate_groups.name: Cryptography
crate_groups.description: Crates that provide implementations of cryptographic algorithms. This section attempts to list the best crates for the listed algorithms, but does not intend to make recommendations for the algorithms themselves.

purposes.name: Password Hashing
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto Password Hashes.

purposes.name: General Purpose Hashing
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto Hashes.

purposes.name: AEAD Encryption
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto AEADs.

purposes.name: Digital Signatures
purposes.notes: For more algorithms, see Rust Crypto Signatures.

crates.name: ed25519
crates.notes: Use in conjunction with the ed25519-dalek crate.

purposes.name: Certificate Formats
purposes.notes: For more formats, see Rust Crypto Formats.

crates.name: rustls
crates.notes: A portable pure-rust high-level implementation of TLS. Implements TLS 1.2 and higher.

crates.name: rust-native-tls
crates.notes: Delegates to the system TLS implementations on windows and macOS, and uses OpenSSL on linux.

crates.name: webpki
crates.notes: X.509 Certificate validation. Builds on top of ring.

crates.name: ring
crates.notes: Fork of BoringSSL. Provides cryptographic primitives for TLS/SSL

crates.name: subtle
crates.notes: Utilities for writing constant-time algorithms

crates.name: zeroize
crates.notes: Securely erase memory

crate_groups.name: Networking
crate_groups.description: TCP, HTTP, GRPc, etc. And the executors required to do asynchronous networking.

subgroups.name: Async Executors
subgroups.description: To do async programming using the async-await in Rust you need a runtime to execute drive your Futures.

crates.name: tokio
crates.notes: The oldest async runtime in the Rust ecosystem and still the most widely supported. Recommended for new projects.

crates.name: async-std
crates.notes: A newer option that is very similar to tokio. Its API more closely mirrors the std library, but it doesn't have as much traction as Tokio.

crates.name: glommio
crates.notes: Use if you need io_uring support. Still somewhat experimental but rapidly maturing.

subgroups.name: HTTP
subgroups.description: HTTP client and server libraries, as well as lower-level building blocks.

crates.name: http
crates.notes: The `http` crate doesn't actually contain an HTTP implementation. Just types and interfaces to help interoperability.

crates.name: hyper
crates.notes: A low-level HTTP implementation (both client and server). Implements HTTP 1, 2, and 3. Requires the tokio async runtime.

crates.name: reqwest
crates.notes: Full-fat HTTP client. Can be used in both synchronous and asynchronous code. Requires tokio runtime.

crates.name: surf
crates.notes: Client that uses the async-std runtime rather than the tokio runtime.

crates.name: ureq
crates.notes: Minimal synchronous HTTP client focussed on simplicity and minimising dependencies.

crates.name: axum
crates.notes: A minimal and ergonomic framework. An official part of the tokio project. Recommend for most new projects.

crates.name: tide
crates.notes: Similar to Axum, but based on async-std rather than tokio

crates.name: actix-web
crates.notes: A performance focussed framework. All Rust frameworks are fast, but choose actix-web if you need the absolutely maximum performance.

crates.name: poem
crates.notes: Automatically generates OpenAPI defintions.

crates.name: warp
crates.notes: Very similar to axum but with a quirkier API. This is a solid framework, but you should probably prefer Axum unless you particular like the API

crates.name: rocket
crates.notes: Focussed on ergonomics. This is a solid framework, however development has stalled. Avoid for new projects.

subgroups.name: Websockets
subgroups.description: This section includes libraries for you to use just websockets. However note that many of the HTTP server frameworks in the section above also support websockets

crates.name: tungstenite-rs
crates.notes: Low-level crate that others build on

crates.name: tokio-tungstenite
crates.notes: If you are using the tokio executor

crates.name: async-tungstenite
crates.notes: If you are using the async-std executor

crates.name: tonic
crates.notes: gRPC over HTTP/2 with full support for asynchronous code. Works with tokio

subgroups.name: Argument Parsing
subgroups.description: See argparse-benchmarks-rs for a full comparison of the crates mentioned here and more.

crates.name: clap
crates.notes: Ergonomic, supports everything, and is fast at runtime. However compile times can be slow

crates.name: lexopt
crates.notes: Fast compile times, fast runtime, pedantic about correctness. API is less ergonomic

crates.name: pico-args
crates.notes: Fast compile times, fast runtime, more lax about correctness. API is more ergonomic

subgroups.name: Utility
subgroups.description: Helpers that are often useful when implementing CLIs

crates.name: globset
crates.notes: High-performance globbing that allows multiple globs to be evaluated at once

crates.name: walkdir
crates.notes: Basic recursive filesystem walking.

crates.name: ignore
crates.notes: Recursive filesystem walking that respects ignore files (like .gitignore)

crates.name: notify
crates.notes: Watch files or directories and execute a function when they change

subgroups.name: Terminal Rendering
subgroups.description: For fancy terminal rendering and TUIs. The crates recommended here work cross-platform (including windows).

crates.name: termcolor
crates.notes: Cross-platform terminal colour output

crates.name: crossterm
crates.notes: Cross-platform terminal rendering and event handling

crates.name: parking_lot
crates.notes: std::mutex also works fine. But Parking Lot is faster.

crates.name: arc_swap
crates.notes: Useful for sharing data that has many readers but few writers

purposes.name: Concurrent HashMap
purposes.notes: See conc-map-bench for comparative benchmarks of concurrent HashMaps.

crates.name: dashmap
crates.notes: The fastest for general purpose workloads

crates.name: flurry
crates.notes: Particularly good for read-heavy workloads.

purposes.name: Channels
purposes.notes: See communicating-between-sync-and-async-code for notes on when to use async-specific channels vs general purpose channels.

crates.name: crossbeam_channel
crates.notes: The absolute fastest channel implementation available. Implements Go-like 'select' feature.

crates.name: flume
crates.notes: Smaller and simpler than crossbeam_channel and almost as fast

crates.name: postage
crates.notes: Channels that integrate nicely with async code

crates.name: rayon
crates.notes: Convert sequential computation into parallel computation with one call - `par_iter` instead of `iter`
